Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: BRCC/LSU - A Partnership for STEM Student Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is expanding an existing partnership between Baton Rouge Community College Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Division (BRCC-STEM) and Louisiana State University College of Engineering (LSU-CoE) to increase STEM students' completion of two year Associates of Science (AS) and Applied Science (AAS) Degrees at BRCC and four year Bachelor of Science (BS) degrees at LSU (emphasizing Engineering/Construction Management - E/CM). One project outcome is to increase the number of BRCC AS/AAS E/CM graduates to 25 annually who have strong academic foundations for further E/CM study at LSU. For LSU, the goal is to improve the overall 2nd-3rd year retention and ultimately the cumulative 6th year graduation rate in engineering by 2-3% annually to the current university average for all entering freshmen (59%). Grounded in the "sense of community" lessons learned from an earlier STEP project, the results of small group discussions with BRCC students and research-based educational practices, these goals are being met through the following actions: 1) designing and implementing a pre-engineering learning community at BRCC; 2) integrating supplemental instruction/academic support such as Peer Lead Team Learning (PLTL) in core STEM/Engineering courses at both institutions; 3) expanding faculty development opportunities and supporting faculty-student interaction/collaboration across institutions that improves student learning; 4) providing the environment and training necessary to develop mentoring relationships among students (particularly transfer students), faculty and practicing professional/industry partners; and 5) implementing mechanisms for effective monitoring and continuous improvement. This project is serving as a model for STEM Student Success.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall, we feel safe in saying that we fulfilled the expectations of this grant. While we did not complete all of our initial goals due to 1) a lack of time resources, and 2) man power.and 3) a continuous change of leadership and initial team players.  However, we do feel that we were very successful in the fulfillment of our primary goal. This being, both identifying, and sustaining STEM students at our institution by supporting them academically and seeing to it that they had a smooth transfer to a four-year STEM program. The primary mechanism for this was through the Supplemental Instruction program strategy, which promoted undergraduate student development both professionally and personally.  The Supplemental Instruction program served as an academic anchor for STEM students by giving them the foundational tools needed to survive and be successful in the historically challenging courses that often cause students in the STEM program to falter.

This program targeted at-risk students, meaning those students who are considered to be at a higher probability of drop out. This group is inclusive of both minorities and females, which are in the under-represented category of this field. This program gave these students the support network that they needed to be successful. By learning to develop their study skills, and to work in groups, they began learning the foundational principles of surviving in this career field of study. Our previous numbers show that we have had a substantial rate of success in this area with the majority of students in our preparatory program transitioning to a four-year institution. . The programs that we maintained assured that our students were supported and assisted in their academic endeavors, which guided them to the next step.

The primary problems that we encountered during this time was turnover in employees and programmatic structural changes. However, with every new addition to this program we became stronger and stronger. In the last phase of the grant, we were even able to include the community at large in our proposal. By bringing middle school aged children in and introducing both them and their instructors to our STEM programs; we started a brand new chapter with this group that very well may mean new STEM enrollee’s in the coming years.

The most challenging component in implementing and sustaining the program as reported previously has been in trying to develop a customized program for our particular community college setting. Many of the aspects of this program model were created around a traditional four-year institution, which differs greatly from the community college setting. We had to work continually to modify the program to fit our demographics, location, and socio-economic status. We also had to find an approach that was fitting to our at risk student population. All of these characteristics along with others were areas that posed great challenges to the success of this program the same way they pose challenges to the academic success and completion of the goals of our students on a daily basis.

However, despite all of these challenges, we feel that we have exceeded our own expectations and developed the beginnings of a great program that we hope to fund and continue in the very near future  

 


Last Modified: 07/08/2019
Modified by: Dennis Taylor
